bioghist.p: Joel (1779-1839) and Isaac Newhall (1782-1858) were partners in a mercantile trade in Salem, Massachusetts. In 1816-1818 they subscribed to the Massachusetts Steam Navigation Company. In the early 1830s, Isaac Newhall engaged in business with a younger brother, George Newhall (1793-1869), proprietor of George Newhall & Company, Boston. By 1836, Isaac had moved to Macon, George, where he arranged shipments of Southern cotton and other agricultural produce. In 1844, Isaac Newhall was living in Lynn, MA. An 1852 letter from Edw. Newhall and Sons, Cincinnati to George Newhall suggests that other relatives were also engaged in the dry goods trade.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of miscellaneous documents related to the business affairs of the Newhalls. Materials documenting the partnership of Joel and Isaac Newhall include incoming letters; receipts; bills of lading; bank notes; accounts recording sales, transfers, and goods sold at auction; and records of shipments of goods between Salem, New York, Boston, ports in Maine, Southern states, and the Caribbean. Other materials document the trade of Isaac Newhall from 1832 to 1853; these records include bills, correspondence, and a marine insurance policy,. Finally, there are several personal papers, including engravings of William Clifton and Benjamin Franklin, and a poem initialed "G.N.," 1830, probably by George Newhall.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
